text: Acknowledgements
label: HH3

text: The research for this report was conducted by Nicholas Bodanac in June and July 2020 as part of the OCHA
label: BODY

text: Centre for Humanitarian Data’s Data Fellows Programme. The research was supervised by Stuart Campo, the
label: BODY

text: lead for the Data Fellows Programme; and Leonardo Milano, team lead for predictive analytics at the Centre. The
label: BODY

text: findings and recommendations draw primarily on interviews with key informants from FAO, IFRC, OCHA and the
label: BODY

text: START Network. Key informants were interviewed on specific projects in Colombia, Sudan, and Bangladesh,
label: BODY

text: while also providing overall guidance of how the sector is utilizing predictive analytics. The author gratefully
label: BODY

text: acknowledges the inputs and feedback from everyone involved in this research.
label: BODY

text: The research findings are presented in a descriptive manner based on the author’s analysis. Given the limited
label: BODY

text: duration of the research and relatively small number of key informants, the findings should not be considered to
label: BODY

text: be representative of the entire humanitarian sector.
label: BODY

text: Page 2 of 22
label: BODY

text: Executive Summary
label: HH2

text: In June and July 2020, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)
label: BODY

text: Centre for Humanitarian Data conducted research through its Data Fellows Programme to better
label: BODY

text: understand the​ existing processes​ for implementing predictive analytics in humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: Through this research, the Centre aimed to answer the following questions:
label: BODY

text: What are the emerging ​best practices​ for model development and use?
label: BODY

text: What ​pitfalls do organizations face​ in using predictive models for anticipatory action?
label: BODY

text: How can we ​improve the implementation​ of predictive analytics in humanitarian settings?
label: BODY

text: The research consisted of a literature review, a series of key informant interviews, and the
label: BODY

text: development of case studies. The literature review focused on technical academic papers,
label: BODY

text: humanitarian project documents, and independent reviews of the application of predictive analytics
label: BODY

text: within the development and humanitarian sectors. (A complete list of resources reviewed is included
label: BODY

text: at the end of this paper​)​.
label: BODY

text: The key informant interviews involved individuals working on predictive analytics with four
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organizations: the International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
label: BODY

text: (IFRC), the START Network, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), and
label: BODY

text: the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). The case studies cover
label: BODY

text: FAO-led pilots in Colombia and Sudan and an OCHA-led pilot in Bangladesh.
label: BODY

text: The key findings from the research are as follows:
label: BODY

text: Many organizations are ​not clear on the questions driving modeling work​ and how
label: BODY

text: predictive analytics fits into their overall situational awareness.
label: BODY

text: Many organizations have ​insufficient expertise​ related to the technical development,
label: BODY

text: contextual adaptation, and programmatic use of models. This ​may lead to inefficient or
label: BODY

text: inaccurate model development​ and could also ​present ethical concerns​.
label: BODY

text: Local participation is essential​ in the design and ownership of predictive models, but is
label: BODY

text: often overlooked or underdeveloped​.
label: BODY

text: Organizations often neglect or fail to properly implement technical review phases​. In
label: BODY

text: some cases, this has led to the implementation of inaccurate models.
label: BODY

text: 1 These questions are based on inputs from the ​Early Action Focus Task Force​, a group of key stakeholders (FAO, IFRC, OCHA,
label: BODY

text: the START Network, and WFP) to ensure collaboration and coherence in anticipatory action in the sector.
label: BODY

text: Page 3 of 22
label: BODY

text: Significant challenges persist in relation to ​data gaps/availability and quality​, limiting the
label: BODY

text: viability and accuracy of model development.
label: BODY

text: Based on these findings, the Centre offers the following six recommendations for improving the
label: BODY

text: implementation of predictive models in support of anticipatory action:
label: BODY

text: Invest in filling data gaps and ensuring that data used for modeling is accurate and
label: BODY

text: complete. ​Accurate data is key to rigorous model development. Predictive models built on
label: BODY

text: incomplete or inaccurate data are of little use. While proxy information such as remote
label: BODY

text: sensing can be helpful in some circumstances, there is a need to invest in primary data
label: BODY

text: gathering to further enhance a model’s accuracy.
label: BODY

text: Involve technical partners, local stakeholders and implementing organizations in the
label: BODY

text: development of triggers and related disaster risk financing frameworks.​ This can improve
label: BODY

text: accuracy of models and foster buy-in for models by local governments and other
label: BODY

text: stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: Build and retain internal technical capacity for model development and use.​ Internal
label: BODY

text: technical capacity should complement working with technical partners and is beneficial to
label: BODY

text: accurately develop models, but also to ensure oversight throughout the program life-cycle.
label: BODY

text: Use predictive models in conjunction with traditional methods of analysis and
label: BODY

text: evaluation. ​While predictive models can highlight the onset of a shock, they should be used
label: BODY

text: alongside other methods such as needs assessments and community perception surveys.
label: BODY

text: Ensure that trigger mechanisms are linked to financial plans.​ The development of
label: BODY

text: standard operating procedures regarding the financial response to a trigger will help avoid
label: BODY

text: delays once a trigger is activated.
label: BODY

text: Engage in multi stakeholder peer review processes with technical and local partners​. This
label: BODY

text: can help ensure the modeling is both technically sound and also reflective of the local context.
label: BODY

text: Page 4 of 22
label: BODY

text: Introduction: Predictive Analytics in the Humanitarian Sector
label: HH2

text: Predictive analytics refers to the use of current and past data to make forecasts about future events.
label: BODY

text: This growing area of analysis includes the application of a range of statistical methods such as big
label: BODY

text: data analysis, machine learning and other modelling techniques that are currently used across a
label: BODY

text: range of disciplines inside and outside of the humanitarian sector.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian action has generally been undertaken in response to a shock or crisis, which can lead to
label: BODY

text: increased costs and a delayed response. As the United Nations​ ​Under-Secretary-General for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Affairs Mark Lowcock has said, humanitarian response is “typically provided only after a
label: BODY

text: disaster is in full swing… suffering is widespread by then… it costs perhaps 50 times as much to save a
label: BODY

text: child who is already suffering from malnutrition as it does to intervene earlier".  The implementation
label: BODY

text: of anticipatory action has the potential to improve the efficiency and speed of humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: While this is a relatively new area for the sector, a number of humanitarian organizations, including
label: BODY

text: IFRC, FAO, the World Health Organization (WHO) and Médecins Sans Frontières​,​ have implemented
label: BODY

text: predictive modelling in response to hazards, migration, disease and famine for many years. For
label: BODY

text: example, the IFRC has progressively developed and improved its forecast-based financing systems
label: BODY

text: since 2008.  As one key informant noted, “there is now new political interest in engaging and building
label: BODY

text: on the work previously conducted” to better integrate predictive analytics within the sector.
label: BODY

text: Predictive models are particularly well-suited to supporting anticipatory action frameworks.
label: BODY

text: Anticipatory action relies on forecasts to trigger funding for predetermined actions ahead of a shock.
label: BODY

text: The aim is to reduce or mitigate the impact of social, environmental or conflict shocks and improve
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response to a crisis. Such frameworks are already in use by a range of organizations and
label: BODY

text: financing mechanisms in the sector, including forecast-based financing, the IFRC Disaster Relief
label: BODY

text: Emergency Fund (​DREF​), the UN’s Central Emergency Response Fund (​CERF​), FAO’s Early Warning
label: BODY

text: Early Action (​EWEA​), and the World Food Programme (WFP)’s ​Emergency Preparedness and Response​.
label: BODY

text: As of September 2020, there were at least 49 initiatives  in the humanitarian sector using predictive
label: BODY

text: methods within their anticipatory action frameworks to inform humanitarian response. (See the
label: BODY

text: Centre’s ​Catalogue of Predictive Models​ to learn more about who is doing what where in the sector).
label: BODY

text: Although organizations have invested significantly in advancing their understanding and use of
label: BODY

text: predictive methods, the implementation of predictive modelling thus far has not been uniform nor
label: BODY

text: sufficiently rigorous in many cases. This poses a risk for the application of predictive analytics in the
label: BODY

text: sector. Models which are not designed, evaluated, updated or understood properly provide limited
label: BODY

text: value to decision makers. Further, the incorrect implementation of models and perceived lack of
label: BODY

text: accuracy may cause stakeholders to withdraw support for such methods.
label: BODY

text: 2 ​https://www.unocha.org/story/un-humanitarian-chief-release-140m-cerf-funds-anticipatory-action-projects
label: BODY

text: 3 Feasibility study on forecast based financing / trigger based action in Malawi, ECHO funded project: Enhancing resilience in
label: BODY

text: Malawi, ​https://europa.eu/capacity4dev/file/74963/download?token=VXaNAvVU
label: BODY

text: 4 Hernandez, K. and Roberts, T. (2020). Predictive Analytics in Humanitarian Action: a preliminary mapping and analysis. K4D
label: BODY

text: Emerging Issues Report 33. Brighton, UK: Institute of Development Studies. ​https://opendocs.ids.ac.uk/opendocs/handle/
label: BODY

text: Page 5 of 22
label: BODY

text: Case Studies
label: HH2

text: The Centre documented the process of a number of pilot projects as part of the research for this
label: BODY

text: paper. The examples are presented through a common structure that examines four steps in the
label: BODY

text: model process: initiation, development, validation, and application. This progression was also used to
label: BODY

text: structure the key informant interviews as a way of better understanding and documenting current
label: BODY

text: practice.
label: BODY

text: While not part of this report, the Centre has also documented how models are maintained and how
label: BODY

text: projections are kept relevant and up-to-date. We have looked at how model inputs are updated and
label: BODY

text: who is responsible for that, how the accuracy of the model is assessed over time as new projections
label: BODY

text: are produced, and who is in charge of monitoring model outputs and sending the trigger signal.
label: BODY

text: We have also documented the roles and responsibilities that different stakeholders have in the
label: BODY

text: process of development and use of predictive analytics.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1: Steps in model development and use
label: BODY

text: FAO early warning early action for drought and food security in Colombia and
label: HH3

text: Sudan
label: HH3

text: In both of the case studies presented below, FAO combined forecasting tools either developed by
label: BODY

text: third parties or their own teams mixed with baseline and community assessments to trigger
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action frameworks.
label: BODY

text: Colombia
label: HH3

text: La Guajira is the driest province of Colombia and many communities have struggled with a history of
label: BODY

text: chronic food insecurity and malnutrition, which has been compounded by the migration crisis from
label: BODY

text: Venezuela.
label: BODY

text: Step 1: Initiation
label: BODY

text: To understand the impact of migration on Colombia’s rural communities, FAO conducted a joint
label: BODY

text: mission in June 2018 with WFP and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) into the departments
label: BODY

text: of La Guajira, Arauca and Norte de Santander. La Guajira was identified as the area of most concern,
label: BODY

text: and consequently was chosen as the pilot location for an early warning early action project.
label: BODY

text: According to FAO staff interviewed, La Guajira was particularly worrying. Findings showed how
label: BODY

text: migration was already affecting food security. FAO complemented these findings with
label: BODY

text: forward-looking analysis to anticipate how food security trends might develop. As opposed to
label: BODY

text: building a model, FAO based their assessment on existing information from other agencies as well as
label: BODY

text: data coming from primary information gathered during their joint mission in June 2018, specifically
label: BODY

text: Page 6 of 22
label: BODY

text: from interviews with local people in La Guajira. This covered issues with inputs to agricultural
label: BODY

text: production, increasing local population and access to water. The information from these assessments
label: BODY

text: pointed to a high likelihood of food security deterioration, according to FAO staff.
label: BODY

text: Step 2: Development
label: BODY

text: While FAO didn’t use a model for migration or to measure agricultural production, they did apply a
label: BODY

text: trigger mechanism based on the onset of drought. Following review of several models from differing
label: BODY

text: agencies, forecasting was used based on drought modelling from the International Research Institute
label: BODY

text: for Climate and Society. The trigger assigned to the drought model was set at a probability of more
label: BODY

text: than 50% of having below normal rainfall between July to October. This time-period is particularly
label: BODY

text: crucial for crop planting in La Guajira.
label: BODY

text: Step 3: Validation
label: BODY

text: While FAO uses triggers to activate early action, they are always combined with some form of human
label: BODY

text: judgement and analysis to validate the trigger system. Consequently, although the drought
label: BODY

text: probability activated the trigger, it was combined with the assessment conducted in June 2018 and
label: BODY

text: presented for a decision by the local country office.
label: BODY

text: Given FAO did not have a full-capacity country office in Colombia compared to other areas, the
label: BODY

text: processes used in this case were not representative of all FAO EWEA systems. In other countries where
label: BODY

text: a full system is in place with regular monthly monitoring, the definition of thresholds and triggers and
label: BODY

text: the combination of different indicators is more structured. FAO combines vulnerability
label: BODY

text: measurements, forecasts and indicators of the agricultural season to periodically assess how it is
label: BODY

text: progressing and what changes may need to be incorporated within early warning early action
label: BODY

text: frameworks. When monitoring slow onset events such as drought, some early signs can be detected
label: BODY

text: using remote sensing or other techniques. This can assist some livelihood groups.
label: BODY

text: Step 4: Application
label: BODY

text: While inputs for the model’s development were agreed upon by a committee of internal and external
label: BODY

text: experts, the country office is responsible for and always operates the trigger, according to FAO staff.
label: BODY

text: Country offices are responsible for producing the evidence for the release of the funds via the Special
label: BODY

text: Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation (SFERA) frameworks. According to FAO staff, funds are
label: BODY

text: released once the trigger is reached.
label: BODY

text: FAO has outlined standard operating procedures which dictate the processes and decisions that
label: BODY

text: country offices and other relevant stakeholders need to take because of this index score and trigger
label: BODY

text: activation. Decision making guidelines are also implemented on the level of probability. A probability
label: BODY

text: of 0-40% will lead to no response, 40-60% will trigger an assessment and 60% or more leads to acting
label: BODY

text: as soon as possible. In the case of La Guajira, a trigger attached to 50% was activated, after which an
label: BODY

text: application for SFERA funding was developed. This request was submitted to a review board
label: BODY

text: combined with the primary assessments conducted during the initiation phase.
label: BODY

text: Page 7 of 22
label: BODY

text: Sudan
label: HH3

text: The project in Sudan was designed to monitor the risk of drought and dry spells in Kassala and Darfur.
label: BODY

text: FAO identified worrying signs of drought in 2017 based on two specific indicators: unusual livestock
label: BODY

text: movement and extended dry spells.
label: BODY

text: Step 1: Initiation
label: BODY

text: FAO’s primary objective was to anticipate drought and the impacts on the most vulnerable
label: BODY

text: populations in the selected communities. The approach and analytical framework took into account
label: BODY

text: all the meteorological and climatological indicators available for the local context which could be
label: BODY

text: used for drought modelling and combined them with a range of socio-economic indicators, such as
label: BODY

text: prices and terms of trade (livestock, maize, etc.).
label: BODY

text: Step 2: Development
label: BODY

text: FAO mapped existing indicators and sources of information and compiled three datasets which
label: BODY

text: included a climate outlook and climate conditions. Assessments were conducted on the reliability and
label: BODY

text: availability of indicators based on the local agricultural season. Following this, the initial list of 40-60
label: BODY

text: measurable indicators was narrowed down to a list of just 15. This process was conducted in
label: BODY

text: consultation with local partners including participants from the head of the national early warning
label: BODY

text: system and the head of a pastoralist group in a village of concern. It was important that
label: BODY

text: representatives of national, regional and local levels, as well as beneficiaries were included within this
label: BODY

text: process.
label: BODY

text: Step 3: Validation
label: BODY

text: Following the consultation process, the country office conducted consultations with HQ-based
label: BODY

text: technical experts to review the index construction and weights and to conduct a deeper analysis on
label: BODY

text: some of the thresholds. The tools were then tested with simulations going back one to two years to
label: BODY

text: see how accurate the results would be. According to FAO staff: “when testing the composite score of
label: BODY

text: 0-100, we wanted to know what a normal record delivered, a score of 50, 60, 70? And from this
label: BODY

text: information, the triggers were re-calibrated”.
label: BODY

text: Step 4: Application
label: BODY

text: The tool was designed to be simple and have zero cost for local stakeholders. It was built in Microsoft
label: BODY

text: Excel and each month new data would be collected and analyzed and then the results would be
label: BODY

text: discussed with the partners. The thresholds were triggered towards the end of the harvest season,
label: BODY

text: highlighting a localized drought. Like the example in Colombia, the results were combined with a
label: BODY

text: field-level assessment that confirmed the model’s trigger activation.
label: BODY

text: One area of improvement highlighted by FAO is the need to do a post-validation assessment of the
label: BODY

text: tool. Although FAO could do more thorough statistical analysis, the availability of data about the local
label: BODY

text: contexts makes it difficult to use time series data needed. Further, as tools are designed to be used by
label: BODY

text: a non-expert at a zero cost, this also limits the technical capacity which goes into their development.
label: BODY

text: Page 8 of 22
label: BODY

text: OCHA Bangladesh early action river flood mechanism
label: HH2

text: In early 2020, the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator, Mark Lowcock, set aside $140 million in CERF
label: BODY

text: funding for anticipatory action pilot mechanisms focusing on drought in Somalia, Ethiopia, Malawi
label: BODY

text: and Chad; cholera outbreaks in sub-Saharan Africa; and floods in Bangladesh.  According to staff
label: BODY

text: interviewed, the goal was to use forecasting measurements with high confidence levels that could be
label: BODY

text: tied to pre-arranged financing mechanisms in order to mitigate the effects of a shock.
label: BODY

text: Under the leadership of the UN Resident Coordinator, the objective of the pilot in Bangladesh was to
label: BODY

text: implement a more effective response in anticipation of severe monsoon flooding of the Jamuna River.
label: BODY

text: Specifically, the pilot focused on the five highly-vulnerable districts of Bogura, Gaibandha, Kurigram,
label: BODY

text: Jamalpur, and Sirajgonj.
label: BODY

text: Step 1: Initiation
label: BODY

text: In the case of Bangladesh, OCHA assessed a range of hazards for whether and how models could be
label: BODY

text: applied to drive an anticipatory response. These included drought, disease outbreak, monsoon floods,
label: BODY

text: earthquakes, and volcanic eruptions. It was decided that focusing on monsoon floods was most
label: BODY

text: appropriate, given that flood warning systems had already been developed for the entire country and
label: BODY

text: allowed for sufficient lead time between the initial trigger (based on a 10-day forecast) and the actual
label: BODY

text: activation, which aligned with OCHA’s pilot framework for anticipatory action.
label: BODY

text: Step 2: Development
label: BODY

text: OCHA decided to make use of models that were already developed, and tailor them to fit the localized
label: BODY

text: frameworks. A technical team assessed a range of models that were developed with high levels of
label: BODY

text: confidence and were verifiable. This included the Centre for Humanitarian Data's predictive analytics
label: BODY

text: team which provided technical support to analyze and validate the thresholds and triggers for the
label: BODY

text: release of funds from the CERF. According to an informant: “A key element of the model design phase
label: BODY

text: was to build as much as possible on models already reviewed and designed to ensure their accuracy
label: BODY

text: was sound".
label: BODY

text: As there are several flood forecasting systems in use for Bangladesh already, there were a number of
label: BODY

text: possibilities to choose from. For example, the local government has several forecasting tools,
label: BODY

text: however, they are all based on a 5-day forecast. The European Commission’s Global Flood Awareness
label: BODY

text: System (GloFAS) flood assessment system includes a 10-day probabilistic forecast and consequently
label: BODY

text: was chosen. The model produces daily probabilistic forecasts 10, 15 and 30 days into the future. The
label: BODY

text: forecasts also include the size of the flood, for example a one in five-year flood, one in ten years, or
label: BODY

text: one in twenty-year event taking place. It was decided that a dual-model system was to be used, one as
label: BODY

text: a pre-activation warning for preparedness and readiness followed by a final activation system.
label: BODY

text: 5 UN humanitarian chief to release up to $140M in CERF funds for anticipatory-action projects, 25 June, 2020​:
label: BODY

text: https://www.unocha.org/story/un-humanitarian-chief-release-140m-cerf-funds-anticipatory-action-projects
label: BODY

text: Page 9 of 22
label: BODY

text: Step 3: Validation
label: BODY

text: Once selected, the models needed to be adjusted to fit the environment and context. Historical data
label: BODY

text: was difficult to acquire and consequently, a technical team had to come to a solution of how to
label: BODY

text: optimize the information they had.
label: BODY

text: The Centre’s predictive analytics team also helped with identifying and implementing better triggers
label: BODY

text: that would fit the local context. This included optimizing the thresholds in collaboration with a
label: BODY

text: technical team of local experts, Bangladesh Red Crescent Society (BDRCS) and OCHA team members.
label: BODY

text: The basis of a two-trigger system was that a pre-activation is 40% likely to be followed by an
label: BODY

text: activation. Consequently the activation system was developed with the following two measurements:
label: BODY

text: First, a 10-day probabilistic warning model based on GloFAS, a global hydrological forecast
label: BODY

text: and monitoring system that couples weather forecasts with a hydrological model and is
label: BODY

text: calibrated for the Jamuna river in Bangladesh.
label: BODY

text: Second, a 5-day deterministic action model, based on the Bangladesh Flood Forecast &
label: BODY

text: Warning Center.
label: BODY

text: Step 4: Application
label: BODY

text: In Bangladesh, the BDRCS employs a scientific team to monitor early warning systems for the entire
label: BODY

text: country. It was noted by OCHA staff that when the scientists flagged the trigger’s activation, the
label: BODY

text: response was immediate with funds being released within hours. It was purposefully planned that no
label: BODY

text: review or committee or decision was needed following the triggers activation, to ensure the rapid
label: BODY

text: response needed for such an event.
label: BODY

text: A strategy was developed around the two different triggers. First, the initial 10-day trigger activation
label: BODY

text: system would release all funds ($5 million) for an initial early action response, following which a
label: BODY

text: response was planned and ready for immediate deployment based on a secondary 5-day trigger
label: BODY

text: mechanism. During this phase, $5 million was released from CERF funding prioritized for early action
label: BODY

text: systems. The funding systems were divided among the relevant agencies as follows: $4.25 million for
label: BODY

text: WFP, including a sub-grant to BDRCS; $500,000 to FAO; and $589,084 for the United Nations
label: BODY

text: Population Fund (UNFPA). It was agreed that there would be no discussion within the program team
label: BODY

text: on what funds were spent and a no regrets approach would be implemented.
label: BODY

text: While there was a limited time-period leading to the 2020 flood season and limited resources, the pilot
label: BODY

text: was able to include three main components. First, together with WFP and the BDRCS, 61,500
label: BODY

text: vulnerable households were to receive US$53 each ahead of a flood (55,500 households via WFP and
label: BODY

text: 6,000 households via BDRCS. While the actual number of households assisted was just 23,000, this was
label: BODY

text: more of a reflection of the outdated population lists used for the vulnerability assessment, which
label: BODY

text: made it difficult to accurately assess the population in need. The FAO also supported 14,000
label: BODY

text: households with livestock protection and flood-proof storage of agricultural and productive assets
label: BODY

text: Page 10 of 22
label: BODY

text: (e.g. tools, seeds). Also, UNFPA distributed reproductive health, menstrual hygiene and dignity kits to
label: BODY

text: some 14,922 vulnerable women and girls.
label: BODY

text: The Bangladesh pilot offers valuable opportunities to learn and to advocate for an expansion of the
label: BODY

text: reach of the anticipatory action so that larger populations at imminent risk can be assisted. OCHA has
label: BODY

text: commissioned an independent evaluation of the individual components of the pilot. The results are
label: BODY

text: expected to be released around March 2021.
label: BODY

text: Page 11 of 22
label: BODY

text: Implementing Predictive Analytics in Support of Anticipatory Action
label: HH2

text: This section presents key findings and recommendations  on the implementation of predictive
label: BODY

text: analytics in support of anticipatory action. It presents more detailed observations across the different
label: BODY

text: stages of model development. It includes a set of questions or considerations for organizations to
label: BODY

text: consider at these different stages in order to overcome some of the challenges identified through the
label: BODY

text: research. These considerations are also summarized in a decision-tree format in Figure 2 below.
label: BODY

text: Figure 2: Key considerations in the model life cycle
label: BODY

text: 6 The findings and recommendations draw primarily on interviews with key informants from FAO, IFRC, OCHA and the START
label: BODY

text: Network. Key informants were interviewed on specific projects in Colombia, Sudan and Bangladesh, while also providing
label: BODY

text: overall guidance of how the sector is utilizing predictive analytics.
label: BODY

text: Page 12 of 22
label: BODY

text: Step 1: Model Initiation
label: HH2

text: According to one key informant, “You can’t wait for the good models to be in place before you start
label: BODY

text: moving in that direction [predictive modelling], it has to be done in parallel [with methodological
label: BODY

text: developments]”. Another key informant stated, “There are still challenges in terms of not setting
label: BODY

text: things up early enough, however, this is currently improving”.
label: BODY

text: When there is a disease outbreak, for example, models must be developed rapidly to estimate the
label: BODY

text: spread of disease or a virus. The risk of waiting far outweighs the time needed to develop more
label: BODY

text: accuracy and consequently strict review processes are often put to the side in favor of a more rapid
label: BODY

text: forecasting. Waiting too long also has the obvious negative effect of unnecessarily extending the
label: BODY

text: human suffering early action is meant to prevent.  However, often in these cases, academic partners
label: BODY

text: or research bodies are brought into develop forecasts for humanitarian implementers given their
label: BODY

text: research is already bounded in peer reviewed frameworks or developed by experts within their field.
label: BODY

text: From a basic economic point of view, it is often costlier to wait too long than to act too early. While
label: BODY

text: there have been some examples of negative economic effects tied to incorrect forecasts. For example,
label: BODY

text: seasonal forecasts in 1998 led farmers to reduce their cropping area in southern Africa, as they
label: BODY

text: interpreted the forecast as a probability of drought rather than an increased chance of below-average
label: BODY

text: rainfall.  However, EWEA programs in Sudan implemented by FAO produced a cost benefit ratio of 6.7,
label: BODY

text: meaning that for every USD 1 invested by FAO, households gained USD 6.7.  The unit cost of food aid
label: BODY

text: can be cut by 30% if procured early, according to a study on aid delivery to Somalia, Kenya and
label: BODY

text: Ethiopia.  Also, ‘acting in vain’ has been justified by a ‘no regrets’ implementation strategy, meaning
label: BODY

text: that spending on people and places that are poor and climate-vulnerable anyway can enhance
label: BODY

text: 7 Hillier and Dempsey, 2012. A Dangerous Delay: The cost of late response to early warnings in the 2011 drought in the Horn of
label: BODY

text: Africa. ​https://www.researchgate.net/publication/263725932_A_Dangerous_Delay_The_cost_of_
label: BODY

text: late_response_to_early_warnings_in_the_2011_drought_in_the_Horn_of_Africa
label: BODY

text: 8 Dilley, M.: Reducing vulnerability to climate variability in Southern Africa: The growing role of climate information, Climatic
label: BODY

text: Change, 45, 63–73, 2000, ​https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1005636932536
label: BODY

text: 9 The Sudan, Impact of Early Warning Early Action, ​http://www.fao.org/3/ca4653en/ca4653en.pdf
label: BODY

text: 10 The Economics of Early Response and Resilience: Approach and Methodology Cabot Venton, 2013. Economics of
label: BODY

text: Resilience. ​https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/57a08a0ae5274a31e00003c0/61114_Approach_
label: BODY

text: and_Methodology.pdf

text: Page 13 of 22
label: BODY

text: At this stage, organizations should consider:
label: BODY

text: What is the problem we are trying to solve?
label: BODY

text: Why can’t we solve it with current methods of analysis?
label: BODY

text: Does predictive modelling fill this gap?
label: BODY

text: Is there available data to use for a model?
label: BODY

text: resilience to future shocks.  However, there are significant financial risks associated with predictive
label: BODY

text: models that can’t be ignored.
label: BODY

text: As predictive analytics gains further attention there is an urge for organizations to implement models
label: BODY

text: without understanding when this is appropriate. Often, organizations start with the mindset of ‘we’re
label: BODY

text: going to build a famine model’ or ‘we’re going to build a drought model’ without understanding
label: BODY

text: whether this is the best way to measure and respond to that particular crisis or shock, or if predictive
label: BODY

text: models are even feasible given the data landscape. Based on the research, integrating predictive
label: BODY

text: approaches is best after an analysis of what the major gaps are in traditional research methods or
label: BODY

text: current use of forecasting.
label: BODY

text: At times, limitations or inaccuracies may be from capacity issues, a lack of localized data, or, poor
label: BODY

text: program management. Engaging with local representatives and assessing the local context is key. This
label: BODY

text: can assist in knowing these limitations or strengths can greatly enhance model development and help
label: BODY

text: to direct efforts in the most efficient way.
label: BODY

text: Data gaps limit how models can be developed. Most organizations using predictive analytics still rely
label: BODY

text: on their own data collection or the use of open source data form local governments and other
label: BODY

text: organizations.  While this is beneficial for some cases, such as WFP’s food security data, in other cases
label: BODY

text: there are significant gaps especially at the local level. Predictive models are dependent on the quality
label: BODY

text: of the data sets on which the models operate and consequently sound data is essential for quality
label: BODY

text: forecasting methods.  Understanding the data landscape and the limitations with available methods
label: BODY

text: is key to deciding whether and, if so, how to utilize predictive models. ​As noted, data availability
label: BODY

text: greatly limits a model’s accuracy and ability to effectively develop early warning models. As one
label: BODY

text: informant noted, “people are developing models without asking questions of what data is going in it.
label: BODY

text: A model is only as good as the information that it feeds off”.
label: BODY

text: Where data gaps exist, it may be tempting for organizations to fill these gaps with proxy information
label: BODY

text: or questionable research methods. The concern of using ‘bad data’ was highlighted by those
label: BODY

text: interviewed who stated that the use of models with bad data or inaccurate information is “completely
label: BODY

text: useless”. There needs to be a more concerted effort to ensure sound practice in sourcing data for use
label: BODY

text: in modeling.
label: BODY

text: Organizations need to understand the data landscape and key actors who may be able to help fill data
label: BODY

text: gaps.​ While remote sensing is used in cases to mitigate this issue, there are limited uses of data
label: BODY

text: collection methods like satellite imagery and other proxy data methods. For example, satellite
label: BODY

text: imagery can provide information on crop patterns but may not deliver information on household
label: BODY

text: 11 ODI Working Paper 547, Scaling Up Early Action, April 2019, ​https://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/
label: BODY

text: resource-documents/12641.pdf
label: BODY

text: 12 Hernandez, K. and Roberts, T. (2020). Predictive Analytics in Humanitarian Action: a preliminary mapping and analysis. K4D
label: BODY

text: Emerging Issues Report 33. Brighton, UK: Institute of Development Studies. ​https://opendocs.
label: BODY

text: ids.ac.uk/opendocs/handle/20.500.12413/15455
label: BODY

text: 13 Predictive analytics in humanitarian action: a preliminary mapping and analysis, K4D, June 2020 ​https://
label: BODY

text: assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/5f0c877ce90e070313365f0d/EIR33_Humanitarian_Predictive_Analytics.pdf
label: BODY

text: Page 14 of 22
label: BODY

text: economic systems.  Further, due to a lack of fishery survey data, predictive models have been used to
label: BODY

text: forecast yield estimates in tropical river and lake fisheries using simple multiple linear regression
label: BODY

text: estimates. However, these models were imprecise and had large error terms.  Consequently, while
label: BODY

text: they were used as a next best estimate their reliability is questionable.
label: BODY

text: Processes need to be put in place and followed to ensure accurate measurements are being applied to
label: BODY

text: direct humanitarian response. ​To assist on this, organizations like FAO have used mixed methods
label: BODY

text: approaches by combining local data collection in target communities in conjunction with forecasting
label: BODY

text: methods to see how the two interact, and to provide better guidance.
label: BODY

text: When designing predictive models, it’s important to understand that their purpose isn’t to be a silver
label: BODY

text: bullet that can take over the sector, rather, as a way of complimenting approaches currently in place.
label: BODY

text: One key informant stated, “humanitarian decisions should not be made alone on predictive analytics.
label: BODY

text: They can support existing approaches”. Organizations like IFRC and FAO use predictive models and
label: BODY

text: forecasts in conjunction with other more standard evaluation methods like baseline assessments and
label: BODY

text: community engagement programs.
label: BODY

text: Step 2: Model Development
label: HH3

text: Predictive models are often implemented to fill a gap, such as a lack of understanding or capacity to
label: BODY

text: measure a shock which leaves humanitarians unprepared or late to assist populations in need.
label: BODY

text: Identifying the source of these gaps can help organizations understand if predictive models are an
label: BODY

text: appropriate tool to fill them. One informant noted “there is a lot of effort and time expended in
label: BODY

text: developing a model without even consulting humanitarian technical experts on the ground. What is
label: BODY

text: being asked or what data is being fed into it?”.
label: BODY

text: Developing and reviewing predictive models effectively requires a mix of technical, quantitative,
label: BODY

text: programmatic, and contextual expertise. When developing a model for a particular context and use
label: BODY

text: 14 AIMS pilot project. Monitoring the rehabilitation of degraded landscapes from Food Assistance for Assets programmes with
label: BODY

text: satellite imagery, September 2017. ​https://docs.wfp.org/api/documents/WFP-0000099680/download/?_ga=2.126610821.
label: BODY

text: 15 FAO predictive yield models for tropical river and lake fisheries, 2006. ​http://www.fao.org/3/ca4475en/ca4475en.pdf
label: BODY

text: Page 15 of 22
label: BODY

text: In this stage, organizations should consider:
label: BODY

text: How can a model compliment existing approaches?
label: BODY

text: Do we have the capacity required to develop and review models?
label: BODY

text: What needs to be outsourced/partnered to develop or review models?
label: BODY

text: How can we involve local stakeholders in model development?
label: BODY

text: How to develop an initial review committee?
label: BODY

text: case, organizations need to consider whether they have the capacities required across these areas.On
label: BODY

text: the technical and quantitative dimension, organizations do not need to internalize all processes
label: BODY

text: themselves. In fact, attempting to do so can deliver poor results for organizations that do not hold the
label: BODY

text: qualification to develop and review predictive and forecasting models. If an organization lacks the
label: BODY

text: technical capacity to develop its own models, building partnerships with external technical teams is a
label: BODY

text: much better solution than attempting the estimations without proper oversight or review.
label: BODY

text: On the programmatic and contextual dimension, organizations need to learn from those with
label: BODY

text: experience in the particular country of interest. Model developers may misjudge or fail to account for
label: BODY

text: variables or local dynamics, just as humanitarians on the ground may misjudge the implications of
label: BODY

text: different forecasting measures, or not have the specific knowledge required to design forecasting
label: BODY

text: measures for a particular context.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data’s ​Peer Review Framework​ ​aims to increase such adaptive measures
label: BODY

text: and to ensure that model structures are followed. Such frameworks can bring in outside thought and
label: BODY

text: expert review early on in the design phase and help direct a model’s development and accuracy.
label: BODY

text: Partnering with local teams, governments and organizations is key to effective model development.
label: BODY

text: All those interviewed acknowledged the importance of understanding local dynamics. One informant
label: BODY

text: stated that there is a need for a more coherent approach in working with local governments and
label: BODY

text: communities. Working directly with local teams was also highlighted by epidemiologists as a huge
label: BODY

text: benefit for overall quality and accuracy.
label: BODY

text: Step 3: Model Validation
label: HH3

text: Model validation should highlight the strengths and weaknesses of the model as well as its proposed
label: BODY

text: use. There is currently no uniform evaluation process with predictive analytics. While some agencies
label: BODY

text: and organizations have stringent methodologies, others are yet to implement stringent approaches
label: BODY

text: and evaluation methods.
label: BODY

text: Once models have been developed, they need to be validated before they can be responsibly used.
label: BODY

text: This process should sit within a technical team or be conducted through a holistic review process form
label: BODY

text: a range of stakeholders. This could include the development of specific reviewers, or review
label: BODY

text: committees, similar to a peer review process for academic research that can validate methods and
label: BODY

text: variables included.
label: BODY

text: Page 16 of 22
label: BODY

text: At this stage, organizations should consider:
label: BODY

text: What processes will be used to incorporate feedback from peer review?
label: BODY

text: How will review processes be established throughout the model life cycle?
label: BODY

text: More consistent approaches to evaluating models before implementation are key to improving the
label: BODY

text: overall accuracy, quality and relevance of predictive analytics in the sector. One informant noted
label: BODY

text: organizations are still far away from this, but this should be a requirement for future projects”. This
label: BODY

text: emphasizes the need for due diligence.
label: BODY

text: A positive example of this is FAO’s method of validation and review. First, there is an initial
label: BODY

text: consultation with key stakeholders during the inception phase, where measurements are reviewed
label: BODY

text: and agreed upon by local stakeholders and partner organizations. Following the development of a risk
label: BODY

text: index which is used as a trigger mechanism, a secondary review is also conducted by a team of
label: BODY

text: internal technical experts. This includes testing the model with historical data, calibrating it, and
label: BODY

text: reviewing methodologies before it is implemented within the program.
label: BODY

text: Model validation is not a one off process. After ​a model has been validated for its intended use case, it
label: BODY

text: may need to be validated again as the context evolves and/or the implementation plan for the model
label: BODY

text: and its outputs changes. ​Data needs to be updated regularly and new information may require for
label: BODY

text: models to be recalibrated. One informant noted, “In my two years working in anticipation design
label: BODY

text: processes, very rarely have there been any kind of technical experts or risk modelers consistently
label: BODY

text: involved (in the project life cycle)”. This leads to questions and risks over how accurate a model is if
label: BODY

text: it’s review process stops at implementation. Having expert review and response integrated
label: BODY

text: throughout the cycle can have an enormous effect on increasing the efficiency of a model and the
label: BODY

text: accuracy of its outputs.
label: BODY

text: As noted earlier, we can’t wait for models to be perfect before we implement. However, once they are
label: BODY

text: being used, they still need regular work. Updating triggers with new data and testing the accuracy
label: BODY

text: does not stop once they have been used. This means new methodologies need to be implemented, or
label: BODY

text: new data inserted to test models accuracy and to keep them current.
label: BODY

text: Step 4: Model Application
label: HH3

text: The application of predictive models to support the implementation of anticipatory action
label: BODY

text: frameworks is based on activating some form of response (financing, the delivery of assistance, etc.)
label: BODY

text: tied to a trigger or warning mechanism. When a certain level of probability or risk is indicated, the
label: BODY

text: release of financial support is often activated.
label: BODY

text: Page 17 of 22
label: BODY

text: At this stage, organizations should consider:
label: BODY

text: How to increase a holistic approach to trigger development, including local ownership?
label: BODY

text: How to enable rapid financial response following trigger activation?
label: BODY

text: How to mitigate risk to ensure local and partner financial support?
label: BODY

text: Local ownership has become a key component for many early warning systems. Consequently having
label: BODY

text: local agencies or local governments buy into the idea and commit financing will require these
label: BODY

text: decisions to be made jointly with expert committees. As a result, the development of a trigger should
label: BODY

text: be a joint effort by technical partners, local stakeholders and implementing organizations.
label: BODY

text: For example, FAO country offices are responsible and always operate their trigger mechanisms,
label: BODY

text: according to staff interviewed. These local offices are responsible for bringing the evidence for the
label: BODY

text: release of the funds. However, these are based on consultations and local agreements with various
label: BODY

text: local partners and committees to discuss trigger warning mechanisms and to ensure a holistic review
label: BODY

text: process is developed at the beginning.
label: BODY

text: When designing triggers, it’s also important to understand how they relate to the financial
label: BODY

text: mechanisms of partner agencies. Some informants noted that developing triggers should be
label: BODY

text: conducted through the ‘impacts before instruments’ idea. This focuses on what impacts can be
label: BODY

text: achieved within their organization and within their capacity. Understanding operational capacity is
label: BODY

text: key in outlining lead times needed and being able to accurately respond to a trigger. IFRC, for
label: BODY

text: example, can deliver cash grants at the household level in Bangladesh within 4 days of a trigger.
label: BODY

text: Once triggers have been activated, the time it takes for finances to be released can require significant
label: BODY

text: time before assistance reaches the area of concern. There needs to be more of a focus toward
label: BODY

text: response actions over “what can be moved, when and how?”. When likelihoods increase, different
label: BODY

text: responses may be needed. Some agencies have response and finance deliverables in place to mitigate
label: BODY

text: this lag and ensure rapid response reaches people in need as quickly as possible. As one informant
label: BODY

text: stated, “There is no point having anticipatory models that are 100% accurate, if financial activation
label: BODY

text: can be delayed for months”. This also needs to be planned with partner organizations who may work
label: BODY

text: on much different time scales. Failure to accurately develop these financing agreements between
label: BODY

text: partner organizations will significantly limit the use for early warning systems.
label: BODY

text: Page 18 of 22
label: BODY

text: Recommendations and Conclusion
label: HH2

text: Based on the research and analysis presented above, the Centre proposes the following six
label: BODY

text: recommendations for improving the implementation of predictive analytics in support of anticipatory
label: BODY

text: action.
label: BODY

text: Invest in filling data gaps and ensure that quality data is used for modeling. ​Accurate data
label: BODY

text: is key to rigorous model development. Predictive models built on incomplete or inaccurate
label: BODY

text: data are of little use. While proxy information such as remote sensing can be helpful in some
label: BODY

text: circumstances, there is a need to invest in primary data gathering to further enhance a
label: BODY

text: model’s accuracy.​ ​In the Bangladesh case study for example, government meteorological data
label: BODY

text: was used, however, the government’s statistical site was prone to crashing.
label: BODY

text: Involve technical partners, local stakeholders and implementing organizations in the
label: BODY

text: development of triggers and related disaster risk financing frameworks. ​This can improve
label: BODY

text: accuracy of models and foster buy-in for models by local governments and other
label: BODY

text: stakeholders. As local ownership is a key component to many early warning systems, having
label: BODY

text: local participation within the design phase is essential.
label: BODY

text: Build and retain internal technical capacity for model development and use.​ Internal
label: BODY

text: technical capacity should complement working with technical partners and is beneficial to
label: BODY

text: accurately develop models, but also to ensure oversight throughout the program life-cycle.
label: BODY

text: Use predictive models in conjunction with traditional methods of analysis and
label: BODY

text: evaluation. ​While predictive models can highlight the onset of a shock, they should be used
label: BODY

text: alongside other methods such as needs assessments and community perception surveys.
label: BODY

text: Models supported by other forms of analysis will lead to a better overall results and more
label: BODY

text: accurate response. For example, organizations such as FAO use local rapid assessments to
label: BODY

text: confirm their activation systems and minimize the risk of ‘activating in vain’.
label: BODY

text: Ensure that trigger mechanisms are linked to financial plans. ​The development of
label: BODY

text: standard operating procedures regarding the financial response to a trigger will help avoid
label: BODY

text: delays once a trigger is activated. The response to a trigger activation needs to be planned and
label: BODY

text: agreed upon before or in conjunction with an early warning system. As many organizations are
label: BODY

text: now taking a ‘no regrets’ approach, this will limit delays in programmatic response. The dual
label: BODY

text: trigger system implemented by OCHA in Bangladesh is also a possibility for organizations
label: BODY

text: looking to limit financial risk in this regard.
label: BODY

text: Engage in multi stakeholder peer review processes with technical and local partners. ​This
label: BODY

text: can help ensure the modeling is both technically sound and also reflective of the local context.
label: BODY

text: Ensuring that organizations have sound internal or external review systems covering the
label: BODY

text: development and application of methodologies is essential to ensuring a model’s accuracy
label: BODY

text: and, consequently, the quality of it’s predictions.
label: BODY

text: Page 19 of 22
label: BODY

text: The Centre will use the findings and recommendations of this research to support the growing
label: BODY

text: number of organizations implementing predictive analytics for anticipatory action. We hope that this
label: BODY

text: report will help to generate a constructive discussion with partners around the use of predictive
label: BODY

text: analytics in humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: Building on the experience from the Bangladesh pilot, OCHA will be scaling up the number of
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action frameworks in 2021 in collaboration with the CERF.
label: BODY

text: The Centre will continue to document ‘who is doing what, where and when’ with predictive models in
label: BODY

text: the ​Catalogue of Predictive Models​ and will support humanitarians to make the best use of predictive
label: BODY

text: models through our ​Peer Review Framework​.
label: BODY
